title: Swirly script engravers font - it's driving me crazy
content:
Hi all -

I've been looking (unsuccessfully) for a script font that has some of the detail in the fill of the letterforms (the little lines) seen in the letters below. Eventually, I'll have to probably draw what I want by hand, but I'm hoping to find a usable substitute to include on mockups...

Any leads?

Thank you thank you!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417022549im_/http:/typophile.com/files/2907077367_24e4f934e9_4931.jpg)
author: miekebl

comments.content:
None of the 'a's are exactly the same - this is hand-drawn calligraphy.

- Lex

Yep, I know it. Pretty much what I'm looking for is a script typeface with this type of shading within the letterforms. On the original, you can see that there are little lines to give the shaded illusion when printed.

hi,

this is the engraving lady and yes, this is engraved, probably by hand.

its not a font. do you have the plate (or die) or just the print.

there are 2 categories for this kind of font available: script and calligraphic (calligraphy.)

the "lines" are either the shadow cast within the "cut" or the guide lines scribed first. neither of which will help you.

if your task is to replicate this, best and (historically "correct" according to the market) is to re-draw it in illustrator. it will be lovely. and maybe you can use the lesson learned for someothing else.

Offhand, the only font I know that has these kinds of fills is [Treasury](http://web.archive.org/web/20150417022549/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/treasury/), a revival of an old MacKellar, Smiths & Jordan 1875 typeface by the same name, by Canada Type. Patrick Griffin and Rebecca Alaccari made a very ornate script with lots of variations that can be used, including two styles of fills.

- Mike Yanega
